skill.name: cirq
skill.description: Quantum computing framework for building, simulating, optimizing, and executing quantum circuits. Use this skill when working with quantum algorithms, quantum circuit design, quantum simulation (noiseless or noisy), running on quantum hardware (Google, IonQ, AQT, Pasqal), circuit optimization and compilation, noise modeling and characterization, or quantum experiments and benchmarking (VQE, QAOA, QPE, randomized benchmarking).
skill.summary: Quantum computing framework for building, simulating, optimizing, and executing quantum circuits. Us...
skill.author: davila7

security_audit.summary: Pure documentation skill containing markdown guides and code examples for the Cirq quantum computing library. No executable scripts, network endpoints, or file operations. All code examples are educational documentation showing legitimate Cirq library usage.

content.value_statement: Quantum computing requires specialized tools for circuit design and simulation. This skill provides comprehensive guidance for Cirq, enabling you to create quantum algorithms, run noisy simulations, and execute on real quantum hardware from multiple providers.
actual_capabilities: Build quantum circuits with gates, measurements, and parameterized operations
Simulate circuits using state vector, density matrix, and stabilizer methods
Run circuits on quantum hardware from Google, IonQ, Azure, AQT, and Pasqal
Model and simulate noise including depolarizing, amplitude damping, and thermal noise
Optimize circuits through gate decomposition, merging, and qubit routing
Implement quantum algorithms including VQE, QAOA, and Quantum Phase Estimation
limitations: Requires Python and Cirq library installation (uv pip install cirq)
Hardware access requires separate accounts and API credentials
Simulation scales exponentially with qubit count (practical limit ~25-30 qubits)
Does not provide quantum hardware itself, only integration interfaces

output_examples.input: Create a quantum circuit that creates a Bell state and run a simulation
output: • Created qubits q0 and q1 using LineQubit
• Applied Hadamard gate to q0 to create superposition
• Applied CNOT with q0 as control and q1 as target for entanglement
• Added measurement on both qubits with key 'result'
• Results show approximately 50/50 distribution between |00⟩ and |11⟩ states

best_practices: Start with simulator testing before running on expensive quantum hardware
Use density matrix simulation only when needed for mixed states or noise
Select best qubits using calibration data to improve hardware results
Optimize circuits for target hardware gateset before submission
anti_patterns: Running unvalidated circuits directly on hardware without simulator testing
Using density matrix simulation for pure state circuits (exponentially slower)
Ignoring device constraints and qubit connectivity when designing circuits
Running simulations with too many qubits without considering memory limits

faq.question: What quantum hardware providers are supported?
faq.answer: Cirq supports Google Quantum AI, IonQ, Azure Quantum, AQT, and Pasqal. Each requires separate API credentials and accounts.

faq.question: How many qubits can I simulate?
faq.answer: Exact simulation scales as 2^n in memory. Practical limits are typically 25-30 qubits (several GB of RAM). Clifford circuits can simulate more efficiently.

faq.question: How do I install Cirq?
faq.answer: Run 'uv pip install cirq' for the core library. Add provider-specific packages like cirq-google, cirq-ionq, or cirq-aqt for hardware access.

faq.question: Is my quantum circuit data safe?
faq.answer: Cirq runs locally. Hardware providers may log submitted circuits for service operation. Review each provider's privacy policy for details.

faq.question: Why is my simulation slow?
faq.answer: State vector simulation is faster than density matrix. Reduce qubits or use CliffordSimulator for Clifford-only circuits. Monitor memory usage.

faq.question: How does Cirq compare to Qiskit?
faq.answer: Cirq focuses on circuit-level design with deep hardware integration. Qiskit offers higher-level abstractions and a larger ecosystem. Choose based on your use case.
